H0.text: The properties of both sodium and chlorine change when they react to form sodium chloride (NaCl), common table salt, because the highly reactive alkali metal sodium and the halogen gas chlorine both lose their individual reactivity and harmful characteristics upon forming the stable compound.

H1.text: The properties of both sodium and chlorine remain the same when they react to form sodium chloride (NaCl), common table salt, even though sodium is an alkali metal that reacts violently with water and chlorine is a halogen gas that can cause respiratory damage.

H2.text: The properties of sodium are different but chlorine remains a dangerous gas when sodium and chlorine react to form sodium chloride, a common table salt.

H3.text: The properties of sodium remain the same but the properties of chlorine change when sodium and chlorine react to form sodium chloride (NaCl), common table salt.

A4.text: The pH of a sodium chloride solution remains ≈7 due to the extremely weak basicity of the Cl− ion, which is the conjugate base of the strong acid HCl.
